title: Three Ways to Test the Same Hypothesis
text: Facebook methods group, question testing hypotheses networks. comments, suggested BGGM used test hypothesis. turns BGGM really shines testing expectations (see example Rodriguez et al. 2020). vignette, demonstrate three ways go testing hypothesis, essentially testing difference sum partial correlations groups.

title: Three Ways to Test the Same Hypothesis
code: # need the developmental version if (!requireNamespace("remotes")) {    install.packages("remotes")    }     # install from github remotes::install_github("donaldRwilliams/BGGM") library(BGGM)

title: Three Ways to Test the Same Hypothesis
text: demonstrative purposes, use bfi data test hypotheses males females
code: # data Y <- bfi  # males Y_males <- subset(Y, gender == 1, select = -c(education, gender))[,1:5]  # females Y_females <- subset(Y, gender == 2, select = -c(education, gender))[,1:5]

title: Three Ways to Test the Same Hypothesis
text: first approach rather straightforward, caveat method needs implemented user. Note certainly implement BGGM, assuming enough interest. Please make feature request .

title: Three Ways to Test the Same Hypothesis
text: hypothesis sum relations larger one group, example, ℋ0:(ρA1−−A2male+ρA1−−A3male)=(ρA1−−A2female+ρA1−−A3female)ℋ1:(ρA1−−A2male+ρA1−−A3male)>(ρA1−−A2female+ρA1−−A3female) \begin{align} \mathcal{H}_0: (\rho^{male}_{A1--A2}\; + \; \rho^{male}_{A1--A3}) = (\rho^{female}_{A1--A2}\; + \; \rho^{female}_{A1--A3}) \\ \mathcal{H}_1: (\rho^{male}_{A1--A2}\; + \; \rho^{male}_{A1--A3}) > (\rho^{female}_{A1--A2}\; + \; \rho^{female}_{A1--A3}) \end{align}  Note hypothesis related sum relations, readily tested BGGM.

title: Three Ways to Test the Same Hypothesis
text: first step estimate model group example, used default assume data Gaussian. can changed type = either binary, ordinal, mixed.
code: # fit female fit_female <- estimate(Y_females, seed = 2)  # fit males fit_male <- estimate(Y_males, seed = 1)

title: Three Ways to Test the Same Hypothesis
text: next step extract posterior samples relation Note column names reflect upper-triangular elements partial correlation matrix. Hence, first name (e.g.,A1) must located second name (e.g., A2) data matrix. can understood reference column numbers: 1--2 correct whereas 2--1 result error.
code: post_male <- posterior_samples(fit_male)[,c("A1--A2", "A1--A3")]  post_female <- posterior_samples(fit_female)[,c("A1--A2", "A1--A3")]

title: Three Ways to Test the Same Hypothesis
text: next step sum relations compute difference can plotted
code: # sum males sum_male <- rowSums(post_male)   # sum females sum_female <- rowSums(post_female)  # difference diff <- sum_male - sum_female # three column par(mfrow=c(1,3))  # male sum hist(sum_male)  # female sum hist(sum_female)  # difference hist(diff)

title: Three Ways to Test the Same Hypothesis
text: Next compute posterior probability sum larger males females credible interval difference
code: # posterior prob mean(sum_male > sum_female)  #> 0.737 quantile(diff, probs = c(0.025, 0.975))  #>        2.5%       97.5%  #> -0.06498586  0.12481253

title: Three Ways to Test the Same Hypothesis
text: next approach based posterior predictive check. hypothesis essentially , predictive distribution, , ℋ0:(ρA1−−A2maleyrep+ρA1−−A3maleyrep)=(ρA1−−A2femaleyrep+ρA1−−A3femaleyrep)ℋ1:(ρA1−−A2maleyrep+ρA1−−A3maleyrep)>(ρA1−−A2femaleyrep+ρA1−−A3femaleyrep) \begin{align} \mathcal{H}_0: (\rho^{male^{yrep}}_{A1--A2}\; + \; \rho^{male^{yrep}}_{A1--A3}) = (\rho^{female^{yrep}}_{A1--A2}\; + \; \rho^{female^{yrep}}_{A1--A3}) \\ \mathcal{H}_1: (\rho^{male^{yrep}}_{A1--A2}\; + \; \rho^{male^{yrep}}_{A1--A3}) > (\rho^{female^{yrep}}_{A1--A2}\; + \; \rho^{female^{yrep}}_{A1--A3}) \end{align}  difference yrepyrep. See details .

title: Three Ways to Test the Same Hypothesis
text: first step define function compute difference sums Note function takes two data matrices returns single value. Also, default BGGM require custom function (needs data group).
code: # colnames cn <- colnames(Y_males)  # function f <- function(Yg1, Yg2){      # data   Yg1 <- na.omit(Yg1)     Yg2 <- na.omit(Yg2)    # estimate partials   fit1 <- pcor_mat(estimate(Yg1, analytic = TRUE))   fit2 <- pcor_mat(estimate(Yg2, analytic = TRUE))      # names (not needed)   colnames(fit1) <- cn   rownames(fit1) <- cn   colnames(fit2) <- cn   rownames(fit2) <- cn      # take sum   sum1 <- fit1["A1", "A2"] + fit1["A1", "A3"]   sum2 <- fit2["A1", "A2"] + fit2["A1", "A3"]      # difference   sum1 - sum2  }

title: Three Ways to Test the Same Hypothesis
text: next step compute observed difference perform check. Note requires user determine α\alpha.
code: # observed obs <- f(Y_males, Y_females)  # check ppc <- ggm_compare_ppc(Y_males, Y_females,                         iter = 250,                         FUN = f,                         custom_obs = obs)  # print ppc  #> BGGM: Bayesian Gaussian Graphical Models  #> ---  #> Test: Global Predictive Check  #> Posterior Samples: 250  #>   Group 1: 896  #>   Group 2: 1813  #> Nodes:  5  #> Relations: 10  #> ---  #> Call:  #> ggm_compare_ppc(Y_males, Y_females, iter = 250, FUN = f, custom_obs = obs) #> ---  #> Custom:  #>   #>    contrast custom.obs p.value #>  Yg1 vs Yg2      0.029   0.264 #> ---

title: Three Ways to Test the Same Hypothesis
text: check can also plotted  red critical region.
code: plot(ppc)

title: Three Ways to Test the Same Hypothesis
text: approaches provide evidence sum equal. words, just difference, provide evidence equality. Bayes factor methods allow formally assessing equality model, , ℋ1:(ρA1−−A2male+ρA1−−A3male)>(ρA1−−A2female+ρA1−−A3female)ℋ2:(ρA1−−A2male+ρA1−−A3male)=(ρA1−−A2female+ρA1−−A3female)ℋ3:notℋ1orℋ2 \begin{align} \mathcal{H}_1&: (\rho^{male}_{A1--A2}\; + \; \rho^{male}_{A1--A3}) > (\rho^{female}_{A1--A2}\; + \; \rho^{female}_{A1--A3}) \\ \mathcal{H}_2&: (\rho^{male}_{A1--A2}\; + \; \rho^{male}_{A1--A3}) = (\rho^{female}_{A1--A2}\; + \; \rho^{female}_{A1--A3}) \\ \mathcal{H}_3&: \text{} \; \mathcal{H}_1 \; \text{} \; \mathcal{H}_2 \end{align} ℋ3\mathcal{H}_3 complement can understood neither first second hypothesis.

title: Three Ways to Test the Same Hypothesis
text: hypothesis easily translated R code Note g1 indicates group ; separates hypotheses. assume data Gaussian (although can changed type = "ordinal" type = "mixed"; see ) Note posterior hypothesis probability equality model 0.825. Bayes factor matrix divides values, example, BF21BF_{21} indicates data 6 times likely ℋ2\mathcal{H}_2 ℋ1\mathcal{H}_1.
code: hyp <- c("g1_A1--A2 + g1_A1--A3 > g2_A1--A2 + g2_A1--A3;            g1_A1--A2 + g1_A1--A3 = g2_A1--A2 + g2_A1--A3") test <- ggm_compare_confirm(Y_males, Y_females,                              hypothesis = hyp)   # print test   #> BGGM: Bayesian Gaussian Graphical Models  #> Type: continuous  #> ---  #> Posterior Samples: 25000  #>   Group 1: 896  #>   Group 2: 1813  #> Variables (p): 5  #> Relations: 10  #> Delta: 15  #> ---  #> Call: #> ggm_compare_confirm(Y_males, Y_females, hypothesis = hyp) #> ---  #> Hypotheses:  #>  #> H1: g1_A1--A2+g1_A1--A3>g2_A1--A2+g2_A1--A3 #> H2: g1_A1--A2+g1_A1--A3=g2_A1--A2+g2_A1--A3 #> H3: complement #> ---  #> Posterior prob:  #>  #> p(H1|data) = 0.13 #> p(H2|data) = 0.825 #> p(H3|data) = 0.046 #> ---  #> Bayes factor matrix:  #>       H1    H2     H3 #> H1 1.000 0.158  2.853 #> H2 6.349 1.000 18.113 #> H3 0.351 0.055  1.000 #> ---  #> note: equal hypothesis prior probabilities

title: Three Ways to Test the Same Hypothesis
text: hypothesis can plotted
code: plot(test)

title: MCMC Diagnostics
text: algorithms BGGM based Gibbs samplers. context covariance matrix estimation, opposed, , say, hierarchical models, allows efficiently sampling posterior distribution. Furthermore, samplers empirical covariance matrix used starting value reduces length burn-(warm-). Still yet important monitor convergence. See introduction MCMC diagnostics.

title: MCMC Diagnostics
text: first example includes “acf” plot looks auto correlation samples. general, want samples strongly correlated related previous samples (lags kk). sure general guidelines, typically want “auto correlation…higher values k, [] indicates high degree correlation samples slow mixing” source example ordinal data. check convergence partial correlation, need parameter name. printed follows Note (Intercept) reflect fact ordinal approach multivariate probit model intercepts. next step make plot  argument param can take number parameters plot made (e.g.., param = c("B1--B2", B1--B3)). case, auto correlations looks acceptable actually really good (note drop zero). problematic acf plot black lines start 1.0 perhaps never go 0.20. make clear, simulated time series data taking code  considered problematic. occurs, one solution thin samples manually perhaps just running model iterations (e.g., increasing iter estimate). quite convoluted note convergence typically issue. might come handy know samples can replaced functions BGGM still work object fit.
code: # data Y <- ptsd[,1:10]  # fit model # + 1 makes first category a 1 fit <- estimate(Y + 1, type = "ordinal") convergence(fit, print_names = TRUE)  #>  [1] "B1--B2"         "B1--B3"         "B2--B3"         "B1--B4"         "B2--B4"         "B3--B4"         "B1--B5"         #>  [8] "B2--B5"         "B3--B5"         "B4--B5"         "B1--C1"         "B2--C1"         "B3--C1"         "B4--C1"         #> [15] "B5--C1"         "B1--C2"         "B2--C2"         "B3--C2"         "B4--C2"         "B5--C2"         "C1--C2"         #> [22] "B1--D1"         "B2--D1"         "B3--D1"         "B4--D1"         "B5--D1"         "C1--D1"         "C2--D1"         #> [29] "B1--D2"         "B2--D2"         "B3--D2"         "B4--D2"         "B5--D2"         "C1--D2"         "C2--D2"         #> [36] "D1--D2"         "B1--D3"         "B2--D3"         "B3--D3"         "B4--D3"         "B5--D3"         "C1--D3"         #> [43] "C2--D3"         "D1--D3"         "D2--D3"         "B1_(Intercept)" "B2_(Intercept)" "B3_(Intercept)" "B4_(Intercept)" #> [50] "B5_(Intercept)" "C1_(Intercept)" "C2_(Intercept)" "D1_(Intercept)" "D2_(Intercept)" "D3_(Intercept)" convergence(fit, param = "B1--B2", type = "acf") # sim time series ts.sim <- arima.sim(list(order = c(1,1,0), ar = 0.7), n = 200)  acf(ts.sim) # extract samples samps <- fit$post_samp$pcors  # iterations iter <- fit$iter  # thinning interval  thin <-  5  # save every 5th (add 50 which is the burnin) new_iter <- length(seq(1,to = iter + 50 , by = thin))  # replace (add 50 which is the burnin) fit$post_samp$pcors <- samps[,,seq(1,to = iter + 50, by = thin)]  # replace iter fit$iter <- new_iter - 50  # check thinned convergence(fit, param = "B1--B2", type = "acf")

title: Custom Network Statistics
text: vignette describes new feature BGGM (2.0.0) allows computing custom network statistics (e.g., centrality). new function called roll_your_own suggested user BGGM (see feature request ).

title: Custom Network Statistics
text: basic idea compute chosen network statistic sampled partial correlation matrices, resulting distribution. required define function takes either partial correlation matrix weighted adjacency matrix (partial correlation matrix values set zero) first argument. Several examples provided .

title: Custom Network Statistics
text: first example computes expected influence (Robinaugh, Millner, McNally 2016). first step define function Note x takes matrix passed expectedInf. ... allows passing additional arguments expectedInf function. example provided . function defined, next step compute network statistic. option select = FALSE indicates compute statistics partial correlation matrices (nothing set zero). can changed select = TRUE. Internally, sampled partial correlation matrices multiplied adjacency matrix. results plotted
code: # define function f <- function(x,...){   networktools::expectedInf(x,...)$step1 } # iter = 250 for demonstrative purposes # (but note even 1000 iters takes less than 1 second) # compute net_stat <- roll_your_own(object = fit,                           FUN = f,                           select = FALSE,                           iter = 250) # print net_stat  #> BGGM: Bayesian Gaussian Graphical Models  #> ---  #> Network Stats: Roll Your Own #> Posterior Samples: 250  #> ---  #> Estimates:  #>  #>  Node Post.mean Post.sd Cred.lb Cred.ub #>     1     0.701   0.099   0.508   0.871 #>     2     0.912   0.113   0.722   1.179 #>     3     0.985   0.112   0.742   1.199 #>     4     1.056   0.105   0.851   1.247 #>     5     1.056   0.116   0.862   1.288 #>     6     0.491   0.092   0.329   0.679 #>     7     0.698   0.098   0.521   0.878 #> --- net_stat <- roll_your_own(object = fit,                           FUN = f,                           select = TRUE,                           iter = 250)  # print net_stat  #> BGGM: Bayesian Gaussian Graphical Models  #> ---  #> Network Stats: Roll Your Own #> Posterior Samples: 250  #> ---  #> Estimates:  #>  #>  Node Post.mean Post.sd Cred.lb Cred.ub #>     1     0.636   0.136   0.386   0.874 #>     2     0.792   0.113   0.580   0.996 #>     3     0.777   0.122   0.544   1.001 #>     4     0.910   0.121   0.667   1.143 #>     5     0.525   0.104   0.331   0.727 #>     6     0.484   0.110   0.270   0.686 #>     7     0.247   0.081   0.088   0.412 #> --- plot(net_stat)

title: Custom Network Statistics
text: next example computes bridge strength (Jones, Ma, McNally 2019). requires user define clusters “communities”. Notice communities. passed ... function f, , turn, passed function bridge. number arguments can passed way. results can plotted customized (returned object ggplot)
code: # clusters communities <- substring(colnames(Y), 1, 1)  # function is slow f <- function(x, ...){ networktools::bridge(x, ...)$`Bridge Strength` }   # compute net_stat <- roll_your_own(object = fit,                           FUN = f,                            communities = communities,                           iter = 250)  # print net_stat  #> BGGM: Bayesian Gaussian Graphical Models  #> ---  #> Network Stats: Roll Your Own #> Posterior Samples: 250  #> ---  #> Estimates:  #>  #>  Node Post.mean Post.sd Cred.lb Cred.ub #>     1     0.162   0.082   0.035   0.347 #>     2     0.250   0.113   0.061   0.501 #>     3     0.180   0.104   0.049   0.480 #>     4     0.280   0.098   0.090   0.480 #>     5     0.375   0.093   0.196   0.558 #>     6     0.617   0.166   0.339   1.002 #>     7     0.628   0.166   0.400   1.025 #> --- plot(net_stat,       fill = "lightblue") +    ggtitle("Bridge Strength") +    xlab("Score")

title: Custom Network Statistics
text: next example computes assortment (Newman 2003). example demonstrate ... can take several arguments. results stored net_stat object. can accessed
code: # clusters communities <- substring(colnames(Y), 1, 1)  # define function f <- function(x,...){   assortnet::assortment.discrete(x, ...)$r }  net_stat <- roll_your_own(object = fit,                           FUN = f,                           types = communities,                           weighted = TRUE,                           SE = FALSE, M = 1,                            iter = 250)  # print net_stat  #> BGGM: Bayesian Gaussian Graphical Models  #> ---  #> Network Stats: Roll Your Own #> Posterior Samples: 250  #> ---  #> Estimates:  #>  #>  Post.mean Post.sd Cred.lb Cred.ub #>      0.261   0.124   -0.01   0.469 #> --- hist(net_stat$results, main = "Assortment")

title: Custom Network Comparisons
text: quite common partial correlation networks (GGMs) various subgroups, say, males females, control treatment group, perhaps several educational levels. case, important determine whether groups different, actually compare groups way answers specific question interest. date, R packages provide ways compare groups, including BGGM (version 1.0.0). version 2.0.0, however, BGGM includes new feature function ggm_compare_ppc enables users compare networks way want.

title: Custom Network Comparisons
text: technical details approach described (Williams et al. 2020). basic idea Draw samples posterior distribution, assuming groups equal (.e., “null” model). Generate posterior predictive distribution chosen test-statistic (groups compared) can understood expect observe future (e.g., replication), assuming groups fact equal. Compute test-statistic observed groups. compare observed test-statistic predictive distribution (expected “null” model). observed error larger model assuming group equality, suggests groups different. BGGM, default compare groups respect (symmetric) Kullback-Leibler divergence (.e., “distance” multivariate normal distributions) sum squared error (partial correlation matrix). shown quite powerful Williams et al. (2020), also low false positive rate. following, focus defining custom functions using ggm_compare_ppc. examples, post-traumatic stress disorder networks compared (Fried et al. 2018).

title: Custom Network Comparisons
text: first example looks correlation partial correlations two networks. Note two networks considered large correlation. However, question , assuming groups equal, just large correlation ? needed interpret observed test-statistic.

title: Custom Network Comparisons
text: first step define custom function takes two data matrices output chosen test-statistic (case correlation)
code: f <- function(Yg1, Yg2){   # number of nodes   p <- ncol(Yg1)      # index of off-diagonal   indices <- upper.tri( diag(p))      # group 1:   # fit model   g1_fit <- estimate(Yg1, analytic = TRUE)   # pcors   g1_pcors <- pcor_mat(g1_fit)[indices]      # group 2   # fit model   g2_fit <- estimate(Yg2, analytic = TRUE)   # pcors   g2_pcors <- pcor_mat(g2_fit)[indices]      # test-statistic   cor(g1_pcors, g2_pcors)   }

title: Custom Network Comparisons
text: next step compute observed test-statistic, , correlation partial correlations.
code: obs <- f(Yg1, Yg2)  # observed obs ## [1] 0.5399268

title: Custom Network Comparisons
text: function, f, observed scores, obs, hand, left predictive check Note loss = FALSE controls p-value computed. indicator whether test-statistic “loss” (bad thing). case, large correlation good thing set FALSE. results can printed shows posterior predictive p-value zero. indicates observed correlation lower entire predictive distribution (distribution correlations future data, assuming group equality) finally plot results  density predictive distribution correlation. Recall correlation expect, given groups actually , black point observed correlation. case, seems quite clear “null model” inadequate–groups apparently quite different.
code: ppc <- BGGM::ggm_compare_ppc(Yg1, Yg2,                         FUN = f,                         custom_obs = obs,                         iter = 1000,                         loss = FALSE) ppc ## BGGM: Bayesian Gaussian Graphical Models  ## ---  ## Test: Global Predictive Check  ## Posterior Samples: 1000  ##   Group 1: 926  ##   Group 2: 956  ## Nodes:  16  ## Relations: 120  ## ---  ## Call:  ## BGGM::ggm_compare_ppc(Yg1, Yg2, iter = 1000, FUN = f, custom_obs = obs,  ##     loss = FALSE) ## ---  ## Custom:  ##   ##    contrast custom.obs p.value ##  Yg1 vs Yg2       0.54       0 ## --- plot(ppc)

title: Custom Network Comparisons
text: first step define custom function takes two data matrices output chosen test-statistic (case Hamming distance)
code: f <- function(Yg1, Yg2){   # nodes   p <- ncol(Yg1)      # index of off-diagonal   indices <- upper.tri( diag(p))    # fit models   fit1 <-  BGGM::estimate(Yg1, analytic = TRUE)   fit2 <-  BGGM::estimate(Yg2, analytic = TRUE)      # select graphs   sel1 <- BGGM::select(fit1)   sel2 <- BGGM::select(fit2)      # hamming distance   sum((sel1$adj[indices] - sel2$adj[indices]) ^ 2) }

title: Custom Network Comparisons
code: f <- function(Yg1, Yg2){   # nodes   p <- ncol(Yg1)      # index of off-diagonal   indices <- upper.tri( diag(p))    # fit models   fit1 <-  BGGM::estimate(Yg1, analytic = TRUE)   fit2 <-  BGGM::estimate(Yg2, analytic = TRUE)      pcor1 <- BGGM::pcor_mat(fit1)    pcor2 <- BGGM::pcor_mat(fit2)      # CDM for partial correlations   # note: numerator is the trace; denominator is the Frobenius norm   1 - (sum(diag(pcor1 %*% pcor2)) / (norm(pcor1, type = "f") * norm(pcor2, type = "f"))) }

title: Custom Network Comparisons
code: # clusters based on DSM-5 comms <- c(   rep("A", 4),   rep("B", 7),   rep("C", 5) )  f <- function(Yg1, Yg2){    fit1 <-  BGGM::estimate(Yg1, analytic = TRUE)   fit2 <-  BGGM::estimate(Yg2, analytic = TRUE)    pcor1 <- BGGM::pcor_mat(fit1)   pcor2 <- BGGM::pcor_mat(fit2)    assort1 <- assortnet::assortment.discrete(pcor1, types = comms,                                          weighted = TRUE,                                          SE = FALSE, M = 1)$r    assort2 <- assortnet::assortment.discrete(pcor2, types = comms,                                           weighted = TRUE,                                           SE = FALSE, M = 1)$r   (assort1 - assort2) }

title: Custom Network Comparisons
text: last example looks expected influence network (Robinaugh, Millner, McNally 2016). case, sum squared error test statistic. computed squared error draw predictive distribution.

title: Custom Network Comparisons
code: f <- function(Yg1, Yg2){    fit1 <-  BGGM::estimate(Yg1, analytic = TRUE)   fit2 <-  BGGM::estimate(Yg2, analytic = TRUE)    pcor1 <- BGGM::pcor_mat(fit1)   pcor2 <- BGGM::pcor_mat(fit2)    ei1 <- networktools::expectedInf(pcor1)$step1     ei2 <- networktools::expectedInf(pcor2)$step1    sum((ei1 - ei2)^2) }

title: Predictability: Binary, Ordinal, and Continuous

code: # need the developmental version if (!requireNamespace("remotes")) {    install.packages("remotes")    }     # install from github remotes::install_github("donaldRwilliams/BGGM") library(BGGM)

title: Predictability: Binary, Ordinal, and Continuous
text: first example looks Binary data, consisting 1190 observations 6 variables. data called women_math variable descriptions provided BGGM. model estimated predictability computed two options plotting. first error bars, denoting credible interval (.e., cred),  second ridgeline plot
code: # binary data Y <- women_math  # fit model fit <- estimate(Y, type = "binary") r2 <- predictability(fit)  # print r2  #> BGGM: Bayesian Gaussian Graphical Models  #> ---  #> Metric: Bayes R2 #> Type: binary  #> ---  #> Estimates: #>  #>  Node Post.mean Post.sd Cred.lb Cred.ub #>     1     0.016   0.012   0.002   0.046 #>     2     0.103   0.023   0.064   0.150 #>     3     0.155   0.030   0.092   0.210 #>     4     0.160   0.021   0.118   0.201 #>     5     0.162   0.022   0.118   0.202 #>     6     0.157   0.028   0.097   0.208 #> --- plot(r2,      type = "error_bar",      size = 4,      cred = 0.90) plot(r2,      type = "ridgeline",      cred = 0.50)

title: Testing Sums

code: # need the developmental version if (!requireNamespace("remotes")) {    install.packages("remotes")    }     # install from github remotes::install_github("donaldRwilliams/BGGM") library(BGGM)

title: Testing Sums
text: first example looks one group, sum tested within ptsd network. focus relations re-experiencing (B) avoidance (C) communities. particular, sum relations “Intrusion” (5 nodes) community “Avoidance” (two nodes) community tested.

title: Testing Sums
text: avoidance symptom “avoidance thoughts” C1, can written R code whereas, avoidance symptom “avoidance reminders” (C2), written Note typically written . paste0 used case avoid typing relations.
code: # ptsd Y <- ptsd  # paste together sums paste0(colnames(Y)[1:5],  "--C1", collapse = " + ")  #> "B1--C1 + B2--C1 + B3--C1 + B4--C1 + B5--C1" paste0(colnames(Y)[1:5],  "--C2", collapse = " + ")  #> "B1--C2 + B2--C2 + B3--C2 + B4--C2 + B5--C2"

title: Testing Sums
text: ordinal GGM fitted +1 changes first category 0 1 (required).
code: fit <- estimate(Y+1, type = "ordinal", iter = 1000)

title: Testing Sums
text: next step use pcor_sum function. First, combine sums one string separated ;. Next pcor_sum used Prob.greater posterior probability first sum larger second sum.
code: # sum 1 sum1 <- paste0(colnames(Y)[1:5],  "--C1", collapse = " + ")  # sum 2 sum2 <- paste0(colnames(Y)[1:5],  "--C2", collapse = " + ")  # paste together sums <- paste(sum1, sum2, sep = ";")  # print sums #> "B1--C1 + B2--C1 + B3--C1 + B4--C1 + B5--C1;B1--C2 + B2--C2 + B3--C2 + B4--C2 + B5--C2" test_sum <- pcor_sum(fit, relations = sums)  # print test_sum  # BGGM: Bayesian Gaussian Graphical Models  # ---  # Network Stats: Posterior Sum # Posterior Samples: 1000  # ---  # Estimates  #  # Sum:  #                                    Post.mean Post.sd Cred.lb Cred.ub # B1--C1+B2--C1+B3--C1+B4--C1+B5--C1     0.215   0.096   0.034   0.404 # B1--C2+B2--C2+B3--C2+B4--C2+B5--C2     0.334   0.097   0.145   0.514 # ---  #  # Difference: # B1--C1+B2--C1+B3--C1+B4--C1+B5--C1 - B1--C2+B2--C2+B3--C2+B4--C2+B5--C2  #  #  Post.mean Post.sd Cred.lb Cred.ub Prob.greater Prob.less #     -0.119   0.145  -0.409   0.173        0.205     0.795 # ---

text: next step fit models
code: # data Y <- bfi  # males Y_males <- subset(Y, gender == 1, select = -c(education, gender))[,1:5]  # females Y_females <- subset(Y, gender == 2, select = -c(education, gender))[,1:5]   fit_female <- estimate(Y_females, seed = 2)  # fit males fit_male <- estimate(Y_males, seed = 1)

code: test_sum <- pcor_sum(fit_female, fit_male, relations = sums)  # print test_sum  #> BGGM: Bayesian Gaussian Graphical Models  #> ---  #> Network Stats: Posterior Sum #> Posterior Samples: 5000  #> ---  #> Estimates  #>  #> Sum:  #>                   Post.mean Post.sd Cred.lb Cred.ub #> g1: A3--A4+A4--A5     0.292   0.026   0.241   0.342 #> g2: A3--A4+A4--A5     0.305   0.036   0.234   0.375 #> ---  #>  #> Difference: #> g1: A3--A4+A4--A5 - g2: A3--A4+A4--A5  #>  #>  Post.mean Post.sd Cred.lb Cred.ub Prob.greater Prob.less #>     -0.014   0.045    -0.1   0.074        0.386     0.614 #> ---

title: Testing Sums
text: kind sanity check, sum male group obtained point estimates. matches output.
code: pcor_mat(fit_male)["A3", "A4"] + pcor_mat(fit_male)["A4", "A5"]   #>  0.305

title: Testing Sums
text: default, print function pcor_sum provides 95 % credible intervals. can changed directly using print function, example print(test_sum, cred = 0.99), provides 99 % credible intervals. Currently, function supports sums, due interest psychological network literature particular. can extended accommodate multiplication, subtraction, testing values zero, etc. Please make feature request either github BGGM-users group.

title: Graphical VAR
text: vignette describes implemention “graphical VAR” BGGM. BGGM, fitted multivariate regression. key innovation novel prior distribution residual covariance matrix. variety much cooler names mere “multivariate regression”, including “VAR” (vector autoregressive models) “TSCGM” (time series chain graphical model).

title: Graphical VAR
text: methods BGGM organized around Bayesian “estimation” “hypothesis testing”. reach broader audience, former similar classical methods (familiar researchers).

title: Graphical VAR
text: data hand, model fitted follows Note beta_sd prior distribution regression coefficients. smaller value, say, beta_sd = 0.25, results Bayesian ridge regression. Note also model, including 5000 draws posterior, estimated less 1 second. results can printed Note coefficients comparable, given variable standardized (e.g., predictors outcome standardized). BGGM compute partial directed correlation (PDC) default (graphicalVAR). standardized effects can readily tested Bayes factor, across within model, whereas seem straightforward PDC (requires transformation).

title: Graphical VAR
text: estimates vars package Recall “estimation” methods similar , case, ordinary least squares. graphical structure BGGM determined credible intervals, quite similar using confidence intervals. Hence researchers unfamiliar Bayesian methods “estimation” methods perhaps nice place start.

title: BGGM
text: R package BGGM provides tools making Bayesian inference Gaussian graphical models (GGM, Williams Mulder 2020). methods organized around two general approaches Bayesian inference: (1) estimation (2) hypothesis testing. key distinction former focuses either posterior posterior predictive distribution (Gelman, Meng, Stern 1996; see section 5 Rubin 1984), whereas latter focuses model comparison Bayes factor (Jeffreys 1961; Kass Raftery 1995).

title: BGGM
text: methods BGGM build upon existing algorithms well-known literature. central contribution BGGM extend approaches: Bayesian estimation novel matrix-F prior distribution (Mulder Pericchi 2018) Estimation (Williams 2018) Bayesian hypothesis testing matrix-F prior distribution (Williams Mulder 2019) Exploratory hypothesis testing Confirmatory hypothesis testing Comparing Gaussian graphical models (Williams 2018; Williams et al. 2020) Partial correlation differences Posterior predictive check Exploratory hypothesis testing Confirmatory hypothesis testing Extending inference beyond conditional ()dependence structure (Williams 2018) Predictability Posterior uncertainty intervals partial correlations Custom Network Statistics computationally intensive tasks written c++ via R package Rcpp (Eddelbuettel et al. 2011) c++ library Armadillo (Sanderson Curtin 2016). Bayes factors computed R package BFpack (Mulder et al. 2019). Furthermore, plotting functions method, control variables can included model (e.g., ~ gender), support missing values (see bggm_missing).

title: BGGM
text: Continuous: continuous method described Williams (2018). Note based customary Wishart distribution. Binary: binary method builds directly upon Talhouk, Doucet, Murphy (2012) , turn, built upon approaches Lawrence et al. (2008) Webb Forster (2008) (name ). Ordinal: ordinal methods require sampling thresholds. two approach included BGGM. customary approach described Albert Chib (1993) (default) ‘Cowles’ algorithm described Cowles (1996). Mixed: mixed data (combination discrete continuous) method introduced Hoff (2007). semi-parametric copula model (.e., copula GGM) based ranked likelihood. Note can used ordinal data (restricted “mixed” data).

print test #> BGGM: Bayesian Gaussian Graphical Models  #> Type: continuous  #> ---  #> Posterior Samples: 250  #>   Group 1: 896  #>   Group 2: 1813  #> Variables (p): 5  #> Relations: 10  #> Delta: 99  #> ---  #> Call: #> ggm_compare_confirm(Ymale, Yfemale, hypothesis = hypothesis,  #>     prior_sd = 0.1, iter = 250, progress = FALSE) #> ---  #> Hypotheses:  #>  #> H1: g1_A1--A2>g2_A1--A2 #> H2: g1_A1--A2<g2_A1--A2 #> H3: g1_A1--A2=g2_A1--A2 #> ---  #> Posterior prob:  #>  #> p(H1|data) = 0.434 #> p(H2|data) = 0.046 #> p(H3|data) = 0.52 #> ---  #> Bayes factor matrix:  #>       H1     H2    H3 #> H1 1.000  9.372 0.835 #> H2 0.107  1.000 0.089 #> H3 1.197 11.219 1.000 #> ---  #> note: equal hypothesis prior probabilities  # indecrease prior SD test <- ggm_compare_confirm(Ymale,                             Yfemale,                             prior_sd = 0.28,                             hypothesis = hypothesis,                             iter = 250,                             progress = FALSE)  # print test #> BGGM: Bayesian Gaussian Graphical Models  #> Type: continuous  #> ---  #> Posterior Samples: 250  #>   Group 1: 896  #>   Group 2: 1813  #> Variables (p): 5  #> Relations: 10  #> Delta: 11.7551  #> ---  #> Call: #> ggm_compare_confirm(Ymale, Yfemale, hypothesis = hypothesis,  #>     prior_sd = 0.28, iter = 250, progress = FALSE) #> ---  #> Hypotheses:  #>  #> H1: g1_A1--A2>g2_A1--A2 #> H2: g1_A1--A2<g2_A1--A2 #> H3: g1_A1--A2=g2_A1--A2 #> ---  #> Posterior prob:  #>  #> p(H1|data) = 0.26 #> p(H2|data) = 0.03 #> p(H3|data) = 0.71 #> ---  #> Bayes factor matrix:  #>       H1     H2    H3 #> H1 1.000  8.730 0.367 #> H2 0.115  1.000 0.042 #> H3 2.728 23.818 1.000 #> ---  #> note: equal hypothesis prior probabilities  ################################ #### example 3: mixed data ##### ################################  hypothesis <- c("g1_A1--A2 >  g2_A1--A2;                  g1_A1--A2 <  g2_A1--A2;                  g1_A1--A2 =  g2_A1--A2")  # print test #> BGGM: Bayesian Gaussian Graphical Models  #> Type: mixed  #> ---  #> Posterior Samples: 250  #>   Group 1: 896  #>   Group 2: 1813  #> Variables (p): 5  #> Relations: 10  #> Delta: 3  #> ---  #> Call: #> ggm_compare_confirm(Ymale, Yfemale, hypothesis = hypothesis,  #>     type = "mixed", iter = 250, progress = FALSE) #> ---  #> Hypotheses:  #>  #> H1: g1_A1--A2>g2_A1--A2 #> H2: g1_A1--A2<g2_A1--A2 #> H3: g1_A1--A2=g2_A1--A2 #> ---  #> Posterior prob:  #>  #> p(H1|data) = 0.028 #> p(H2|data) = 0.091 #> p(H3|data) = 0.882 #> ---  #> Bayes factor matrix:  #>        H1    H2    H3 #> H1  1.000 0.307 0.032 #> H2  3.261 1.000 0.103 #> H3 31.734 9.732 1.000 #> ---  #> note: equal hypothesis prior probabilities  ############################## ##### example 4: control ##### ############################## # print test #> BGGM: Bayesian Gaussian Graphical Models  #> Type: continuous  #> ---  #> Posterior Samples: 250  #>   Group 1: 896  #>   Group 2: 1813  #> Variables (p): 5  #> Relations: 10  #> Delta: 3  #> ---  #> Call: #> ggm_compare_confirm(Ymale, Yfemale, hypothesis = hypothesis,  #>     iter = 250, progress = FALSE) #> ---  #> Hypotheses:  #>  #> H1: g1_A1--A2>g2_A1--A2&g1_A1--A3=g2_A1--A3 #> H2: g1_A1--A2=g2_A1--A2&g1_A1--A3=g2_A1--A3 #> H3: g1_A1--A2=g2_A1--A2=g1_A1--A3=g2_A1--A3 #> H4: complement #> ---  #> Posterior prob:  #>  #> p(H1|data) = 0.118 #> p(H2|data) = 0.873 #> p(H3|data) = 0.006 #> p(H4|data) = 0.003 #> ---  #> Bayes factor matrix:  #>       H1    H2      H3      H4 #> H1 1.000 0.135  19.490  36.820 #> H2 7.414 1.000 144.499 272.984 #> H3 0.051 0.007   1.000   1.889 #> H4 0.027 0.004   0.529   1.000 #> ---  #> note: equal hypothesis prior probabilities # title: GGM Compare: Posterior Predictive Check — ggm_compare_ppc
text: Interpretation: primary test-statistic symmetric KL-divergence termed Jensen-Shannon divergence (JSD). essence likelihood ratio provides "distance" two multivariate normal distributions. basic idea (1) compute posterior predictive distribution, assuming group equality (null model). provides error expect see null model; (2) compute JSD observed groups; (3) compare observed JSD posterior predictive distribution, posterior predictive p-value computed. global check, sum squared error also provided. computed partial correlation matrices analagous strength test van2017comparing;textualBGGM. nodewise test compares posterior predictive distribution node. based correspondence inverse covariance matrix multiple regresssion kwan2014regression,Stephens1998BGGM. null model rejected, note provide evidence equality! , null model rejected, means assumption group equality tenable–groups different. Alternative Methods: several methods BGGM comparing groups. See ggm_compare_estimate (posterior differences partial correlations), ggm_compare_explore (exploratory hypothesis testing), ggm_compare_confirm (confirmatory hypothesis testing).

title: GGM Compare: Posterior Predictive Check — ggm_compare_ppc
code: # \donttest{ # note: iter = 250 for demonstrative purposes  # data Y <- bfi  ############################# ######### global ############ #############################   # males Ym <- subset(Y, gender == 1,              select = - c(gender, education))  # females  Yf <- subset(Y, gender == 2,              select = - c(gender, education))   global_test <- ggm_compare_ppc(Ym, Yf,                                iter = 250) #> BGGM: Predictive Check (Contrast 1) #> BGGM: Finished  global_test #> BGGM: Bayesian Gaussian Graphical Models  #> ---  #> Test: Global Predictive Check  #> Posterior Samples: 250  #>   Group 1: 805  #>   Group 2: 1631  #> Nodes:  25  #> Relations: 300  #> ---  #> Call:  #> ggm_compare_ppc(Ym, Yf, iter = 250) #> ---  #> Symmetric KL divergence (JSD):  #>   #>    contrast JSD.obs p_value #>  Yg1 vs Yg2   0.442       0 #> ---  #>   #> Sum of Squared Error:  #>   #>    contrast SSE.obs p.value #>  Yg1 vs Yg2   0.759       0 #> ---  #> note: #> JSD is Jensen-Shannon divergence    ############################# ###### custom function ###### ############################# # example 1  # maximum difference van Borkulo et al. (2017)  f <- function(Yg1, Yg2){  # remove NA x <- na.omit(Yg1) y <- na.omit(Yg2)  # nodes p <- ncol(Yg1)  # identity matrix I_p <- diag(p)  # partial correlations  pcor_1 <- -(cov2cor(solve(cor(x))) - I_p) pcor_2 <- -(cov2cor(solve(cor(y))) - I_p)  # max difference max(abs((pcor_1[upper.tri(I_p)] - pcor_2[upper.tri(I_p)])))  }  # observed difference obs <- f(Ym, Yf)  global_max <- ggm_compare_ppc(Ym, Yf,                               iter = 250,                               FUN = f,                               custom_obs = obs,                               progress = FALSE)  global_max #> BGGM: Bayesian Gaussian Graphical Models  #> ---  #> Test: Global Predictive Check  #> Posterior Samples: 250  #>   Group 1: 805  #>   Group 2: 1631  #> Nodes:  25  #> Relations: 300  #> ---  #> Call:  #> ggm_compare_ppc(Ym, Yf, iter = 250, FUN = f, custom_obs = obs,  #>     progress = FALSE) #> ---  #> Custom:  #>   #>    contrast custom.obs p.value #>  Yg1 vs Yg2       0.16    0.02 #> ---    # example 2 # Hamming distance (squared error for adjacency)  f <- function(Yg1, Yg2){  # remove NA x <- na.omit(Yg1) y <- na.omit(Yg2)  # nodes p <- ncol(x)  # identity matrix I_p <- diag(p)  fit1 <-  estimate(x, analytic = TRUE) fit2 <-  estimate(y, analytic = TRUE)  sel1 <- select(fit1) sel2 <- select(fit2)  sum((sel1$adj[upper.tri(I_p)] - sel2$adj[upper.tri(I_p)])^2)  }  # observed difference obs <- f(Ym, Yf)  global_hd <- ggm_compare_ppc(Ym, Yf,                             iter = 250,                             FUN = f,                             custom_obs  = obs,                             progress = FALSE)  global_hd #> BGGM: Bayesian Gaussian Graphical Models  #> ---  #> Test: Global Predictive Check  #> Posterior Samples: 250  #>   Group 1: 805  #>   Group 2: 1631  #> Nodes:  25  #> Relations: 300  #> ---  #> Call:  #> ggm_compare_ppc(Ym, Yf, iter = 250, FUN = f, custom_obs = obs,  #>     progress = FALSE) #> ---  #> Custom:  #>   #>    contrast custom.obs p.value #>  Yg1 vs Yg2         75     0.6 #> ---    ############################# ########  nodewise ########## #############################  nodewise <- ggm_compare_ppc(Ym, Yf, iter = 250,                            test = "nodewise") #> BGGM: Predictive Check (Contrast 1) #> BGGM: Finished  nodewise #> BGGM: Bayesian Gaussian Graphical Models  #> ---  #> Test: Nodewise Predictive Check  #> Posterior Samples: 250  #>   Group 1: 805  #>   Group 2: 1631  #> Nodes:  25  #> Relations: 300  #> ---  #> Call:  #> ggm_compare_ppc(Ym, Yf, test = "nodewise", iter = 250) #> ---  #> Symmetric KL divergence (JSD):  #>   #> Yg1 vs Yg2  #>  Node JSD.obs p_value #>     1   0.001   0.648 #>     2   0.000   0.952 #>     3   0.006   0.088 #>     4   0.005   0.252 #>     5   0.006   0.064 #>     6   0.002   0.472 #>     7   0.000   0.776 #>     8   0.000   0.856 #>     9   0.000   0.936 #>    10   0.003   0.216 #>    11   0.020   0.016 #>    12   0.009   0.020 #>    13   0.003   0.284 #>    14   0.004   0.112 #>    15   0.011   0.016 #>    16   0.001   0.464 #>    17   0.000   0.616 #>    18   0.000   0.636 #>    19   0.000   0.764 #>    20   0.000   0.708 #>    21   0.000   0.892 #>    22   0.003   0.484 #>    23   0.002   0.376 #>    24   0.013   0.176 #>    25   0.018   0.044 #> ---  #>  #> note: #> JSD is Jensen-Shannon divergence   # }

text: ... object class estimate. can either one two fitted objects. iter Number iterations (posterior samples; defaults number object). relations Character string. partial correlations summed?

title: Partial Correlation Sum — pcor_sum
text: object class posterior_sum, including sum possibly difference two sums.

title: Partial Correlation Sum — pcor_sum
text: care must taken writing string partial_sum. several examples Just Sum: Perhaps sum interest, necessarily difference two sums. can written partial_sum <-  c("A1--A2 + A1--A3 + A1--A4") sum relations. Comparing Sums: comparing sums, must seperated ";". example, partial_sum <-  c("A1--A2 + A1--A3; A1--A2 + A1--A4") sum compute difference. Note two sums, c("A1--A2 + A1--A3; A1--A2 + A1--A4; A1--A2 + A1--A5") result error. Comparing Groups: one fitted object suppled object assumed groups compared sum. Hence, case, sum needs written. partial_sum <-  c("A1--A2 + A1--A3 + A1--A4") results sum computed group compared.

title: Partial Correlation Sum — pcor_sum
code: # \donttest{ # data Y <- bfi  # males Y_males <- subset(Y, gender == 1, select = -c(education, gender))[,1:5]  # females Y_females <- subset(Y, gender == 2, select = -c(education, gender))[,1:5]  # males fit_males <- estimate(Y_males, seed = 1,                       progress = FALSE)  # fit females fit_females <- estimate(Y_females, seed = 2,                         progress = FALSE)   sums <- pcor_sum(fit_males,                  fit_females,                  relations = "A1--A2 + A1--A3") # print sums #> BGGM: Bayesian Gaussian Graphical Models  #> ---  #> Network Stats: Posterior Sum #> Posterior Samples: 5000  #> ---  #> Estimates  #>  #> Sum:  #>                   Post.mean Post.sd Cred.lb Cred.ub #> g1: A1--A2+A1--A3    -0.314   0.039  -0.392  -0.239 #> g2: A1--A2+A1--A3    -0.344   0.026  -0.394  -0.293 #> ---  #>  #> Difference: #> g1: A1--A2+A1--A3 - g2: A1--A2+A1--A3  #>  #>  Post.mean Post.sd Cred.lb Cred.ub Prob.greater Prob.less #>       0.03   0.047  -0.062   0.123        0.742     0.258 #> ---   # plot difference plot(sums)[[3]] #> `stat_bin()` using `bins = 30`. title: Prior Belief Gaussian Graphical Model — prior_belief_ggm
code: # \donttest{ # Assume perfect prior information # synthetic ggm p <- 20 main <- gen_net()  # prior odds 10:1, assuming graph is known prior_ggm <- ifelse(main$adj == 1, 10, 1)  # generate data y <- MASS::mvrnorm(n = 200,                    mu = rep(0, 20),                    Sigma = main$cors)  # prior est prior_est <- prior_belief_ggm(Y = y,                               prior_ggm = prior_ggm,                               progress = FALSE)  # check scores BGGM:::performance(Estimate = prior_est$adj,                    True = main$adj) #> $results #>       measure     score #> 1 Specificity 0.9849624 #> 2 Sensitivity 0.6491228 #> 3   Precision 0.9487179 #> 4      Recall 0.6491228 #> 5    F1_score 0.7708333 #> 6         MCC 0.7194326 #>   # default in BGGM default_est <- select(explore(y, progress = FALSE))  # check scores BGGM:::performance(Estimate = default_est$Adj_10,                    True = main$adj) #> $results #>       measure     score #> 1 Specificity 0.9849624 #> 2 Sensitivity 0.3508772 #> 3   Precision 0.9090909 #> 4      Recall 0.3508772 #> 5    F1_score 0.5063291 #> 6         MCC 0.4809824 #>   # }

title: Compute Custom Network Statistics — roll_your_own
text: user complete control function. Hence, care must taken FUN returns format. function return single number (one entire GGM) vector (one node). ensures print plot.roll_your_own work. select = TRUE, graph selected network statistics computed based weigthed adjacency matrix. accomplished internally multiplying sampled partial correlation matrices adjacency matrix.

title: Compute Custom Network Statistics — roll_your_own
code: # \donttest{ #################################### ###### example 1: assortment ####### #################################### # assortment library(assortnet)  Y <- BGGM::bfi[,1:10] membership <- c(rep("a", 5), rep("c", 5))  # fit model fit <- estimate(Y = Y, iter = 250,                 progress = FALSE)  # membership membership <- c(rep("a", 5), rep("c", 5))  # define function f <- function(x,...){  assortment.discrete(x, ...)$r }   net_stat <- roll_your_own(object = fit,                           FUN = f,                           types = membership,                           weighted = TRUE,                           SE = FALSE, M = 1,                           progress = FALSE)  # print net_stat #> BGGM: Bayesian Gaussian Graphical Models  #> ---  #> Network Stats: Roll Your Own #> Posterior Samples: 250  #> ---  #> Estimates:  #>  #>  Post.mean Post.sd Cred.lb Cred.ub #>      0.364   0.101   0.172   0.552 #> ---    ############################################ ###### example 2: expected influence ####### ############################################ # title: VAR: Estimation — var_estimate
text: Estimate VAR(1) models efficiently sampling posterior distribution. provides two graphical structures: (1) network undirected relations (GGM, controlling lagged predictors) (2) network directed relations (lagged coefficients). Note graphical modeling literature, model also known time series chain graphical model abegaz2013sparseBGGM.

title: VAR: Estimation — var_estimate
code: var_estimate(   Y,   rho_sd = sqrt(1/3),   beta_sd = 1,   iter = 5000,   progress = TRUE,   seed = NULL,   ... )

title: VAR: Estimation — var_estimate
text: Y Matrix (data frame) dimensions n (observations)  p (variables). rho_sd Numeric. Scale prior distribution partial correlations, approximately standard deviation beta distribution (defaults sqrt(1/3) results delta = 2, uniform distribution across partial correlations). beta_sd Numeric. Standard deviation prior distribution regression coefficients (defaults 1). prior default centered zero follows normal distribution @Equation 9, @sinay2014bayesianBGGM iter Number iterations (posterior samples; defaults 5000). progress Logical. progress bar included (defaults TRUE) ? seed integer random seed (defaults 1). ... Currently ignored.

title: VAR: Estimation — var_estimate
text: object class var_estimate containing lot information used printing plotting results. users BGGM, following useful objects: beta_mu matrix including regression coefficients (posterior mean). pcor_mu Partial correlation matrix (posterior mean). fit list including posterior samples.

title: VAR: Estimation — var_estimate
text: time series Y standardized (mean  = 0; standard deviation = 1).

title: VAR: Estimation — var_estimate
text: Regularization: Bayesian ridge regression can fitted decreasing beta_sd (e.g., beta_sd = 0.25). advantageous forecasting (--sample prediction) particular.

title: VAR: Estimation — var_estimate

title: Zero-Order Correlations — zero_order_cors
text: Estimate zero-order correlations type data. Note zero-order refers fact variables controlled (.e., bivariate correlations). knowledge, Bayesian implementation R can estiamte Pearson's,  tetrachoric (binary), polychoric (ordinal two cateogries), rank based correlation coefficients.

title: Zero-Order Correlations — zero_order_cors
code: zero_order_cors(   Y,   type = "continuous",   iter = 5000,   mixed_type = NULL,   progress = TRUE )

title: Zero-Order Correlations — zero_order_cors
text: Y Matrix (data frame) dimensions n (observations)  p (variables). type Character string. type data Y ? options include continuous, binary, ordinal, mixed. See note details. iter Number iterations (posterior samples; defaults 5000). mixed_type Numeric vector. indicator length p varibles treated ranks. (1 rank 0 assume normality). default currently treat integer variables ranks type = "mixed" NULL otherwise. See note details. progress Logical. progress bar included (defaults TRUE) ?

title: Zero-Order Correlations — zero_order_cors
text: R array including correlation matrices               (dimensions p p iter) R_mean Posterior mean correlations (dimensions p p)

title: Zero-Order Correlations — zero_order_cors
text: Mixed Type: term "mixed" somewhat misnomer, method can used data including  continuous discrete variables. based ranked likelihood requires sampling  ranks variable (.e., data merely transformed ranks). computationally  expensive many levels. example, continuous data, many ranks  data points! option mixed_type allows user determine  variable treated ranks  "emprical" distribution used otherwise hoff2007extendingBGGM.  accomplished specifying indicator vector length p. one indicates use ranks,  whereas zero indicates "ignore" variable. default integer variables treated ranks. Dealing Errors: error likely arise type = "ordinal". two common errors (although still rare): first due sampling thresholds, especially data heavily skewed.       can result ill-defined matrix. occurs, recommend first try       decreasing prior_sd (.e., informative prior). work,       change data type type = mixed estimates copula GGM       (method can used data containing ordinal variable).       work without problem. second due ordinal data categorized. example, error states        index bounds, indicates first category zero. allowed,        first category must one. addressed adding one (e.g., Y + 1) data matrix.

title: Zero-Order Correlations — zero_order_cors
code: # \donttest{ # note: iter = 250 for demonstrative purposes  Y <- ptsd[,1:3]  ################################# ####### example 1: Pearson's #### #################################  fit <- zero_order_cors(Y, type = "continuous",                        iter = 250,                        progress = FALSE)   ################################# ###### example 2: polychoric #### #################################  fit <- zero_order_cors(Y+1, type = "ordinal",                        iter = 250,                        progress = FALSE)   ########################### ##### example 3: rank ##### ###########################  fit <- zero_order_cors(Y+1, type = "mixed",                        iter = 250,                        progress = FALSE)  ############################ ## example 4: tetrachoric ## ############################  # binary data Y <- women_math[,1:3]  fit <- zero_order_cors(Y, type = "binary",                        iter = 250,                        progress = FALSE)  # }

title: BGGM (development version)
text: Addressed CRAN check error building vignettes. Downgraded required R version 4.0.0

title: BGGM 2.1.3
text: CRAN release: 2024-07-05 Replaced dprecated armadillo function conv_to<>::as_scalar prior_sd: Adjusted computation delta. Also, changed default value estimation: sqrt(1/3) resulting delta = 2. model testing default tight, sigma_sd = 0.5, resulting delta = 3. prior_sd now limited range 0 – sqrt(1/2)

title: BGGM 2.1.2
text: CRAN release: 2024-06-22 prior_sd (rho_sd var_estimate() ) limited ranges 0 sqrt(1/8). values ensure delta go 1. Critical: select() return partial correlations, Fisher-z values summary(). Fisher values transformed back correlation metric. fixes #90, see changes. Upgraded deprecated ggplot guides() argument Resolved non positive definite initialization matrix wishrnd() copula models NA’s present observed variables (fixes #89). See changes

title: BGGM 2.1.1
text: CRAN release: 2024-02-23 BFpack dependency error fixed.

title: BGGM 2.0.1
text: CRAN release: 2020-07-23 version BGGM included changes based JOSS reviews: see overview specific issues.

title: BGGM 2.0.0
text: CRAN release: 2020-05-31 BGGM almost completely rewritten version 2.0.0. due adding support binary, ordinal, mixed data, required methods written c ++. Unfortunately, result, lots code version 1.0.0 broken.

title: BGGM 2.0.0
text: Full support binary, ordinal, mixed data. implemented argument type roll_your_own: compute custom network statistics weighted adjacency matrix partial correlation matrix pcor_to_cor: convert sampled partial correlation matrices correlation matrices. zero_order_cors: compute zero order correlations convergence: acf trace plots posterior_samples: extract posterior samples regression_summary: summarize multivariate regression pcor_sum: Compute compare partial correlation sums weighted_adj_mat: Extract Weighted Adjacency Matrix pcor_mat: Extract Partial Correlation Matrix Five additional data sets added.

title: BGGM 2.0.0
text: ggm_compare_ppc: added option custom network statistics Added option control variables formula progress bar added many functions
